sections.heading: IntroDuctIon
sections.text:
Noble metal nanomaterials, especially Au nanomaterials, have received great research interest because of their high chemical stability, excellent biocompatibility, unique electronic structure and outstanding LSPR absorption property, making them attractive in many important applications, such as biosensing1,2, controlled release3, near-infrared photothermal therapy4,5, catalysis6–10, SERS11,12 and energy conversion13. The physical and chemical properties of Au nanomaterials can be effectively tailored by controlling their size, shape and architecture14,15. As the first colloidal Au nanoparticles were synthesized by Faraday in the 1850s16, many kinds of synthetic methods, such as seeded growth17,18, surfactant-mediated synthesis19 and aluminum anodic oxide (AAO)-templated growth20, have been developed, resulting in the formation of Au nanomaterials with tunable and well-defined size, shape and architecture. Taking the shape as a representative example, spherical nanoparticles21, nanorods19,22, nanocages23,24, nanowires25–28, nanoprisms29,30, nanodisks31, nanosheets32,33, nanostars34,35, multipods36, nanoribbons37 and nanopolyhedra38–42 of Au have been successfully synthesized. However, the crystal structure of all the aforementioned Au nanomaterials is limited to the thermodynamically stable and face-centered cubic (fcc) phase.
Besides the control of size, shape and architecture, synthesis of unusual crystal structures would produce a new generation of Au nanomaterials with unique physical and chemical properties. Note that recent studies have revealed that the crystal structure of other noble metal nanomaterials can markedly change their properties43–47. For instance, it was observed that the chemical stability of FePt nanoparticles is greatly enhanced by changing their crystal structure from fcc to unusual face-centered
tetragonal phases48. Another investigation found that the fcc Ru nanoframes exhibit superior catalytic activity over the general hcp Ru nanowires (NWs)49. Moreover, a recent study showed that the LSPR absorption in the visible region of 4H Ag NWs is much stronger than that in the common fcc counterparts50. Therefore, development of synthetic strategies toward the crystalphase control of Au nanomaterials could substantially improve and promote their properties and applications.
Traditionally, high temperature and high pressure have been used for the synthesis of noble metal nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures46,47,51,52. Unfortunately, under such harsh conditions, ultrathin and anisotropic Au nanomaterials could easily become aggregated or even be destroyed. In addition to the high-temperature and high-pressure approaches, alternative methods, including direct current magnetron sputtering53, AAOtemplated electrochemical deposition54, the polyol method55,56 and solvothermal synthesis57, have also been used for the crystalphase control of noble metal nanomaterials. However, these methods involve high vacuum, multiple steps and high temperatures. Furthermore, although these methods are quite effective for the synthesis of Ag, Ru and Rh nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures, they could not be used to synthesize the Au nanomaterials with unusual phases.
Recently, our group has developed a series of wet chemical methods for the crystal-phase-controlled synthesis of Au nanomaterials58–61. In 2011, our group first reported the synthesis of pure hcp Au square sheets (AuSSs) using a graphene oxide (GO)mediated approach61. Simultaneously, by changing the solvent used in the synthetic system of hcp AuSSs, well-dispersed ultrathin Au NWs containing alternating hcp/fcc phases on GO were synthesized58. Gold (au) nanomaterials have attracted wide research attention, owing to their high chemical stability, promising catalytic properties, excellent biocompatibility, unique electronic structure and outstanding localized surface plasmon resonance (lspr) absorption properties; all of which are closely related to their size and shape. recently, crystal-phase-controlled synthesis of noble metal nanomaterials has emerged as a promising strategy to tune their physicochemical properties. this protocol describes the detailed experimental procedures for the crystal-phase-controlled syntheses of au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures under mild conditions. Briefly, pure hexagonal close-packed (hcp) au square sheets (ausss) with a thickness of ~2.4 nm are synthesized using a graphene-oxide-assisted method in which Haucl4 is reduced by oleylamine in a mixture of hexane and ethanol. By using pure hexane as the solvent, well-dispersed ultrathin hcp/face-centered cubic (fcc) au nanowires with a diameter of ~1.6 nm on graphene oxide can be obtained. Meanwhile, hcp/fcc au square-like plates with a side length of 200–400 nm are prepared via the secondary growth of au on the hcp ausss. remarkably, hexagonal (4H) au nanoribbons with a thickness of 2.0–6.0 nm can be synthesized with a one-pot colloidal method in which Haucl4 is reduced by oleylamine in a mixed solvent of hexane and 1,2- dichloropropane. It takes 17–37 h for the synthesis of these au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures. transmission electron microscopy (teM) and atomic force microscopy (aFM) are used to characterize the resultant au nanomaterials, which could have many promising applications, such as biosensing, near-Ir photothermal therapy, catalysis and surface-enhanced raman scattering (sers).

Very recently, for the first time, Au nanoribbons (NRBs) with an unprecedented 4H hexagonal structure, which has a typical stacking sequence of ABCB in the [001]4H close-packed direction, were synthesized via a one-pot colloidal method60. Notably, we also observed that surface ligand exchange on the surface of hcp AuSSs could induce a complete phase transformation of AuSSs from the pure (110)h-oriented hcp to (100)f-oriented fcc phases62, which is also applicable to 4H Au NRBs60. In addition, we found that through the coating of a thin metal film on the hcp AuSSs or 4H Au NRBs, unusual crystal structures of other noble metal and alloy nanomaterials can be achieved, including hcp Ag and 4H Pd, Ag, Pt, Ir, Os, Ru, Rh, PtAg, PdAg and PtPdAg nanostructures60,62–64. Importantly, as compared with the other crystal-phase-controlled synthetic methods of noble metal nanomaterials, our wet chemical synthetic methods are relatively simple and straightforward, and can be conducted under mild conditions. Note that our methods can be carried out at normal pressure and at low reaction temperatures (55–58 °C, e.g., for the synthesis of hcp AuSSs, hcp/fcc Au NWs, hcp/fcc AuSPs and 4H Au NRBs) or even at room temperature (i.e., 22 °C in our laboratory, e.g., for the epitaxial growth of 4H Pd, Pt, Ir, Os, Ru and Rh nanostructures on 4H Au NRBs).
In this protocol, we describe the detailed procedures for the controlled synthesis and characterization of Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures, such as hcp AuSSs, hcp/fcc Au NWs, hcp/fcc AuSPs and 4H Au NRBs. Here, we show how to tune the crystal structure of Au nanomaterials by rational control of the experimental conditions. Particularly, we observe that the solvent used in the reaction systems markedly affects the crystal structure of the resultant Au nanomaterials58–61. We believe that this protocol will promote the crystal-phase-controlled synthesis of Au nanomaterials and thus benefit their various potential applications.

sections.heading: Applications
sections.text:
Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures obtained by this protocol have large aspect ratios in terms of edge length to thickness (for hcp AuSSs and hcp/fcc AuSPs), length to diameter (for hcp/fcc Au NWs), and length and width to thickness (for 4H Au NRBs), and thus they could exhibit strong LSPR absorption in a wide range from visible to IR regions. As a typical example, we have found that 4H Au NRBs show quite strong LSPR absorption in both the visible and the IR regions based on the monochromated electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) study of individual Au NRBs60. Moreover, it is well known that Au nanomaterials have excellent biocompatibility and high chemical stability15. These intriguing properties make the obtained Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures promising in a variety of biorelated applications, such as biosensing and near-IR photothermal therapy. The LSPR of Au nanomaterials is very sensitive to changes in the dielectric constant of the local environment2,65. As a result, the obtained Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures should be applicable to the refractive-index-sensing of various biomolecules by monitoring the shift of their LSPR absorption peaks. Because of the strong LSPR absorption of Au nanomaterials in the IR region, they have outstanding photothermal conversion efficiency4. So they may also find applications in near-IR photothermal therapy.
In additon, owing to the unique electronic structure of Au nanomaterials, they have been widely used for many catalytic applications, such as carbon monoxide oxidation66, reduction of nitroaromatic compounds67 and photocatalytic degradation of organic dyes68. Importantly, a previous study has suggested that the electronic structure of noble metal nanomaterials can be manipulated by changing their crystal structures50. Therefore, the obtained Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures are expected to show unique or improved catalytic properties toward various chemical reactions. Meanwhile, as the obtained Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures possess sharp edges/corners, which have particularly strong local electromagnetic fields and generate plasmonic hotspots69,70, they hold great promise for use as effective SERS substrates as well.
On the basis of our preliminary studies, our nanomaterials can be functionalized via ligand exchange with other surfactants such as thiol molecules. No obvious differences between our nanomaterials and gold nanoparticles are observed in terms of the functionalization. More studies are still needed to address this point. Therefore, we did not mention the functionalization of our nanomaterials here.

sections.heading: Limitations
sections.text: This protocol is primarily intended to be used for the crystal-phasecontrolled synthesis of Au nanomaterials. As for the synthesis of other metal or alloy nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures, substantial modifications of the protocol might be necessary. Note that the direct crystal-phase-controlled synthesis of other metal or alloy nanomaterials, such as Pd, Pt and AuCu nanostructures, could provide an alternative strategy to further improve their physicochemical properties and thus benefit their potential applications. Furthermore, to make it applicable to in vivo experiments, the size of Au nanomaterials should be < 10 nm so as to ensure efficient renal clearance. Note that the size limit for renal filtration is 10 nm71. Currently, although the thickness of Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures is just a few nanometers, their width, length or edge length is > 10 nm (see ANTICIPATED RESULTS). We will continue devoting our efforts toward the size reduction of Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures.

sections.heading: Experimental design
sections.text:
Generally, the Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures, i.e., hcp AuSSs, hcp/fcc Au NWs, hcp/fcc AuSPs and 4H Au NRBs in this protocol (Fig. 1), are synthesized by the reduction of HAuCl4 with oleylamine in organic solvents. During the synthesis process, the oleylamine molecules function as not only the reducing agent but also as the surface ligand to regulate the growth process of Au nanomaterials. After the synthesis, oleylamine molecules can stabilize the obtained Au nanomaterials through interaction between the –NH2 groups and Au atoms. Note that the hcp AuSSs, hcp/fcc Au NWs and 4H Au NRBs are synthesized with a one-pot reaction method, whereas hcp/fcc AuSPs are prepared by a twostep method, i.e., using the presynthesized hcp AuSSs as seeds for the secondary growth of Au.
In the synthesis of hcp AuSSs, hcp/fcc Au NWs and hcp/fcc AuSPs, GO sheets are introduced into their growth solutions. Although hcp AuSSs, hcp/fcc Au NWs and hcp/fcc AuSPs can also be obtained in the absence of GO, the yield is much lower as compared with our results. GO sheets are rich in oxygen-containing functional groups72

As a result, GO sheets could promote the assembly of oleylamine molecules in solution via hydrophobic interaction between the sp2conjugated aromatic domains of GO and the long hydrocarbon chains of oleylamine, and thus contribute to the anisotropic growth of Au nanomaterials. In addition, because of the hydrophobic interaction between GO and oleylamine, the resultant Au nanomaterials are well-dispersed on GO sheets. Note that the obtained Au nanomaterials are capped by oleylamine molecules.
The 4H Au NRBs are synthesized by a one-pot colloidal method without GO sheets. In addition, the solvent systems used for the synthesis of hcp AuSSs, hcp/fcc Au NWs and 4H Au NRBs differ strongly. The solvents used for the synthesis of hcp AuSSs, hcp/fcc Au NWs and 4H Au NRBs are a hexane/ethanol mixture, pure
hexane and a hexane/1,2-dichloropropane mixture, respectively. This suggests that the solvent system is also a critically important experimental factor that can greatly affect the crystal structure, as well as the morphology of the resultant Au nanomaterials. Therefore, it is expected that new crystal structures of Au nanomaterials could be obtained by systematically tuning the solvent in the colloidal synthesis.
All reagents and solvents can be used as received without any further drying or purification. The Au precursor, i.e., HAuCl4, easily deliquesces in air and decomposes under light irradiation, resulting in its uncertain stoichiometry. Therefore, special care should be taken during the weighing and storage of HAuCl4.
GO is intrinsically a mixture and its synthesis might differ from batch to batch, so we recommend preparing a stock suspension of GO before its use in order to minimize uncertainty in the synthesis of hcp AuSSs, hcp/fcc Au NWs and hcp/fcc AuSPs as a result of GO batch-to-batch variability. In other words, the detailed synthetic conditions of these Au nanomaterials might require slight modification for different batches of GO. If trying to scale up the synthesis of Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures, complications could arise from insufficient mass transport of Au precursors in the reaction solution. Note that the synthesis of Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures is realized without stirring, and the intermediates tend to sink to the bottom of the glass vial. Therefore, in order to scale up the reaction, we suggest increasing the volume of the reaction solution and using a glass vial with larger volume.
The obtained Au nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures will be systematically characterized by TEM and/or AFM. TEM is one of the most straightforward and powerful methods for investigating the size, shape, composition and crystal structure of nanomaterials. Meanwhile, AFM is a simple and sensitive method for measuring the thickness and size of nanomaterials. Importantly, an advantage of both methods is that only very small amounts of sample are required. In this protocol, we describe how to use TEM to characterize the crystal structure, as well as the size and shape, of the obtained Au nanomaterials. Furthermore, AFM will be used to measure the thickness of the obtained AuSPs.

EQUIPMENT SETUP Au nanomaterial synthesis setup This setup consists of a polyethylene snapcapped glass vial, a water bath and a hot plate equipped with a temperature controller and a thermocouple. The growth solution of Au nanomaterials is loaded into the polyethylene snap-capped glass vial, which is then sealed with PTFE tape and Parafilm. A 500-ml beaker filled with water serves as the water bath. The beaker is capped with aluminum foil to avoid water loss by evaporation. A hot plate equipped with a temperature controller is used to heat the water bath. The thermocouple is inserted into the water bath to monitor the heating temperature. Note that an appropriate and small pinhole is punched in the aluminum foil for inserting the thermocouple into the water bath. A typical setup is shown in Figure 2. In a typical experiment, the liquid level of water in the 500-ml beaker should be ~4 mm higher than that of the growth solution of Au nanomaterials in the glass vial. TEM setup In our laboratory, TEM characterization is performed on a JEOL JEM-2100F TEM instrument. The TEM is operated with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The TEM samples are prepared by dropping Au nanomaterials onto full carbon-coated copper grids and then drying them slowly under ambient conditions. Dilute solutions of Au nanomaterials in hexane are used for sample preparation in order to avoid the agglomeration of Au nanomaterials. AFM setup In our laboratory, AFM characterization is performed on a Veeco Dimension 3100 AFM instrument. The AFM is operated with a Si tip (spring constant: 42 N/m; resonance frequency: 320 kHz) in the tapping mode. The AFM samples are prepared by dropping hcp/fcc AuSPs onto a SiO2-coated Si substrate and then dried slowly under ambient conditions. The AFM image is acquired with a scanning rate of 1 Hz and a scanning line of 512 in air. Dilute solutions of AuSPs in hexane are used for sample preparation in order to avoid the agglomeration of AuSPs.

The two diffraction rings in Figure 3c,d are attributed to the (100) and (110) planes of GO.
Synthesis of hcp/fcc Au NWs In Step 1B(xi), well-dispersed ultrathin hcp/fcc Au NWs on GO were obtained (Fig. 4). The average diameter of Au NWs is ~1.6 nm (Fig. 4a,b). The Au NWs demonstrate growth directions of < 002 > h/ < 111 > f. A typical HRTEM image of Au NWs indicates the alternating growth of the hcp and fcc phases, together with stacking faults (Fig. 4b). The lattice spacing of 2.4 Å is assigned to the interplanar distance of close-packed planes in the [001]h/[111]f directions. Figure 4c shows a representative SAED pattern of Au NWs, in which a discrete diffraction ring is derived from the Au (002)h/(111)f planes. The other two diffraction rings in Figure 4c are attributed to the (100) and (110) planes of GO. It should be mentioned that if the experimental conditions are not optimized, for example, if water is present in the reaction solution, many Au nanoparticles, i.e., the byproduct, can be formed together with the hcp/fcc Au NWs (Fig. 5).
Synthesis of hcp/fcc AuSPs In Step 1C(xiv), well-dispersed hcp/fcc AuSPs on GO were obtained (Fig. 6). The edge length and average thickness in the center region of AuSPs are 200–400 nm and ~5.0 nm, respectively (Fig. 6a). Figure 6b shows the AFM image of a typical AuSP. The section analysis reveals that the thicknesses of the edge and center regions of AuSPs are ~8.8 and 6.5 nm, respectively. The measured thickness in the center region of AuSPs as determined by AFM is ~1.5 nm larger than that determined by TEM. Note that the thickness measured by AFM includes that of oleylamine molecules adsorbed on the surface of AuSPs. Therefore, the thickness of the edge region of AuSPs is ~7.3 nm after the reduction of 1.5 nm. The SAED pattern of a representative AuSP reveals the alternating growth of the hcp and fcc phases, together with stacking faults and twin structures (Fig. 6c,d). Note that the diffraction streaks along the [001]4H direction are derived from the stacking faults and twin structures (Fig. 6d). HRTEM images of AuSPs suggest that the edge region is pure fcc phase, whereas the center region consists of alternating hcp and fcc phases, which is further confirmed by the corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) patterns (Fig. 6e,f).

sections.heading: Synthesis of 4H Au NRBs
sections.text:
In Step 1D(x), freestanding 4H Au NRBs were obtained, as shown in Figure 7. The width and thickness of Au NRBs are 2.0–6.0 nm and 15–61 nm, respectively (Fig. 7a,b). The Au NRBs demonstrate a growth direction of < 004 > 4H (Fig. 7c,d). A representative SAED pattern of Au NRBs collected from the [110]4H zone axis reveals the single-crystalline 4H phase (Fig. 7d). An HRTEM image of Au NRBs further confirms their unusual 4H phase, demonstrating a characteristic stacking sequence of ABCB in the close-packed direction of [001]4H (Fig. 7e). The lattice spacings of 2.4 and 2.5 Å are assigned to the interplanar distances of the (004)4H and (11 −0)4H planes, respectively.

metadata.abstractText: nature protocols | VOL.12 NO.11 | 2017 | 2367 IntroDuctIon Noble metal nanomaterials, especially Au nanomaterials, have received great research interest because of their high chemical stability, excellent biocompatibility, unique electronic structure and outstanding LSPR absorption property, making them attractive in many important applications, such as biosensing1,2, controlled release3, near-infrared photothermal therapy4,5, catalysis6–10, SERS11,12 and energy conversion13. The physical and chemical properties of Au nanomaterials can be effectively tailored by controlling their size, shape and architecture14,15. As the first colloidal Au nanoparticles were synthesized by Faraday in the 1850s16, many kinds of synthetic methods, such as seeded growth17,18, surfactant-mediated synthesis19 and aluminum anodic oxide (AAO)-templated growth20, have been developed, resulting in the formation of Au nanomaterials with tunable and well-defined size, shape and architecture. Taking the shape as a representative example, spherical nanoparticles21, nanorods19,22, nanocages23,24, nanowires25–28, nanoprisms29,30, nanodisks31, nanosheets32,33, nanostars34,35, multipods36, nanoribbons37 and nanopolyhedra38–42 of Au have been successfully synthesized. However, the crystal structure of all the aforementioned Au nanomaterials is limited to the thermodynamically stable and face-centered cubic (fcc) phase. Besides the control of size, shape and architecture, synthesis of unusual crystal structures would produce a new generation of Au nanomaterials with unique physical and chemical properties. Note that recent studies have revealed that the crystal structure of other noble metal nanomaterials can markedly change their properties43–47. For instance, it was observed that the chemical stability of FePt nanoparticles is greatly enhanced by changing their crystal structure from fcc to unusual face-centered tetragonal phases48. Another investigation found that the fcc Ru nanoframes exhibit superior catalytic activity over the general hcp Ru nanowires (NWs)49. Moreover, a recent study showed that the LSPR absorption in the visible region of 4H Ag NWs is much stronger than that in the common fcc counterparts50. Therefore, development of synthetic strategies toward the crystalphase control of Au nanomaterials could substantially improve and promote their properties and applications. Traditionally, high temperature and high pressure have been used for the synthesis of noble metal nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures46,47,51,52. Unfortunately, under such harsh conditions, ultrathin and anisotropic Au nanomaterials could easily become aggregated or even be destroyed. In addition to the high-temperature and high-pressure approaches, alternative methods, including direct current magnetron sputtering53, AAOtemplated electrochemical deposition54, the polyol method55,56 and solvothermal synthesis57, have also been used for the crystalphase control of noble metal nanomaterials. However, these methods involve high vacuum, multiple steps and high temperatures. Furthermore, although these methods are quite effective for the synthesis of Ag, Ru and Rh nanomaterials with unusual crystal structures, they could not be used to synthesize the Au nanomaterials with unusual phases. Recently, our group has developed a series of wet chemical methods for the crystal-phase-controlled synthesis of Au nanomaterials58–61. In 2011, our group first reported the synthesis of pure hcp Au square sheets (AuSSs) using a graphene oxide (GO)mediated approach61.
